abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Amino-terminal (Nt-) acetylation (NTA) is a common protein modification, affecting 80% of cytosolic proteins in humans. The human essential gene, <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic>, encodes for the enzyme NAA10, which is the catalytic subunit in the N-terminal acetyltransferase A (NatA) complex, also including the accessory protein, NAA15. The full spectrum of human genetic variation in this pathway is currently unknown. Here we reveal the genetic landscape of variation in <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>NAA15</jats:italic> in humans. Through a genotype-first approach, one clinician interviewed the parents of 56 individuals with <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic> variants and 19 individuals with <jats:italic>NAA15</jats:italic> variants, which were added to all known cases (<jats:italic>N</jats:italic> = 106 for <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>N</jats:italic> = 66 for <jats:italic>NAA15</jats:italic>). Although there is clinical overlap between the two syndromes, functional assessment demonstrates that the overall level of functioning for the probands with <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic> variants is significantly lower than the probands with <jats:italic>NAA15</jats:italic> variants. The phenotypic spectrum includes variable levels of intellectual disability, delayed milestones, autism spectrum disorder, craniofacial dysmorphology, cardiac anomalies, seizures, and visual abnormalities (including cortical visual impairment and microphthalmia). One female with the p.Arg83Cys variant and one female with an <jats:italic>NAA15</jats:italic> frameshift variant both have microphthalmia. The frameshift variants located toward the C-terminal end of <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic> have much less impact on overall functioning, whereas the females with the p.Arg83Cys missense in NAA10 have substantial impairment. The overall data are consistent with a phenotypic spectrum for these alleles, involving multiple organ systems, thus revealing the widespread effect of alterations of the NTA pathway in humans.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare no competing interests.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: Both oral and written patient consent were obtained for research and publication, with approval of protocol #7659 for the Jervis Clinic by the New York State Psychiatric Institute - Columbia University Department of Psychiatry Institutional Review Board. Written family consent was given for publication of any photography of the children.
